Class Cardinal

java.lang.Object
org.interworldtransport.cladosF.Cardinal
public final class Cardinal extends Object
This class is a simple string holder that names a division field in a manner similar to the concept of 'units' in a physical model. Examples... "metres", "litres", "amperes". There is no requirement one use a particular standard for unit systems, though. They are free strings.

Cardinals are meant to provide all DivFields instances with a single object they may share that names them in order to speed field comparisons in TypeMatch methods. A class using fields for calculations would declare only one of these and then share the reference among all the objects that may be operated upon by the two primary opertaions of the field. ( +, * )

This may seem like a waste of time, but it is useful when a class must be prepared to use different kinds of fields without knowing in advance which one will be created. It is most important when an object exists that uses DivFields with unknown pedigrees. The Cardinal can be checked to discover intended uses and avoid mixing apples and oranges.

One consequence of this approach is that two division fields might use different Cardinal objects of the same name. The TypeMatch method in a ProtoN will state that they are different because object equality is tested instead of string content equality. This allows an application writer to keep two distinct systems of numbers apart in their application even though the fields are internally identical. This is useful when objects in one algebra might be scaled different than objects in another. If one never intends to use this feature, though, it is easy to avoid. Simply re-use a Cardinal.

Yes. This is soft typing to an OOP developer. The point is that it allows for differences between objects that can't assume 'scale' means the same thing to both of them. Since 'scale' and 'multiply' are NOT the same concepts, this distinction is needed in some scenarios.

Version:
2.0
Author:
Dr Alfred W Differ

  • Method Details

    • generate

      public static final Cardinal generate(CladosField pT)
      When one does not wish to use Cardinals much, the best bypass is to use this factory method to create a minimal cardinal. The unit value will be set to the name of the CladosField offered
      Parameters:
      pT - CladosField Name the element of the enumeration will be re-used as the unit value within the Cardinal.
      Returns:
      Cardinal

    • generate

      public static final Cardinal generate(String pT)
      When one does wish to use Cardinals, the best approach is to use this factory method to create a typical cardinal. The unit value is set to the string.
      Parameters:
      pT - String The Cardinal's unit value will be set to this string.
      Returns:
      Cardinal

    • toXMLString

      public static final String toXMLString(Cardinal pCard, String indent)
      Similar to a toString() method, but it focuses upon an XML style output.
      Parameters:
      pCard - Cardinal to be exported as XML.
      indent - String to assist with human readability of XML output.
      Returns:
      String XML compatible sub-unit for code relying on export-able Cardinals.
